subject: Enforce D-Bus busconfig ACLs.
commitMessage:
Enforce D-Bus busconfig ACLs.

This change is a part of the privilege seperation work
which is tracked in:
  https://github.com/openbmc/openbmc/issues/3383

Tested: manual inspection under qemu/evb for the following targets:
  gsj, evb-npcm750, palmetto, romulus, tiogapass, witherspoon, zaius

Test plan:
1. Check failed services via "systemctl | grep failed" and inspect logs
2. Run ipmitool with "mc info", "sensors", "lan print" and inspect logs

Signed-off-by: Anton D. Kachalov <gmouse@google.com>
Change-Id: I3b682749ac15b424fd46f016f8ebb28b3b6feb65

Patch Set 13: Code-Review-1

I had an offline discussion with Brad about this because I'm not convinced on the direction here yet.  Overall I'd like to see the following:

1. Smaller changes.  Wholesale adds of these config files across the whole code base is too much change in one commit.

2. Configs supplied by repos.  A package should know what it wants to provide for dbus config and so it should be responsible for it, and not the meta-phosphor layer.

3. A design doc.  I think we have some fundamental disagreements (even within the maintainers) of how these configs should be provided: by the dbus service or the client.  I'd like to see a small design of what you're proposing and what your stages are to get there.

Patch Set 13:

> Patch Set 13: Code-Review-1
> 
> I had an offline discussion with Brad about this because I'm not convinced on the direction here yet.  Overall I'd like to see the following:
> 
> 1. Smaller changes.  Wholesale adds of these config files across the whole code base is too much change in one commit.

With smaller change we will not have a per-repo impact. No one will be noticed if something is broken after several months before we enforce busconfig acls. For example, it happened several times already when some daemons add new endpoints. The purpose to have one big changelist is that the changes are identical across different services. Once maintainers starts to review, it will be easier to follow. 

> 2. Configs supplied by repos.  A package should know what it wants to provide for dbus config and so it should be responsible for it, and not the meta-phosphor layer.

As per example with the certificate manager, this approach, the correct one, I agreed, will take almost forever with only one engineer being assigned for the work. And almost every time we will hit the same problem to bump openbmc main repo -- the individual repo's changes will be blocked until then. We had this situation already a week or two ago.
 
> 3. A design doc.  I think we have some fundamental disagreements (even within the maintainers) of how these configs should be provided: by the dbus service or the client.  I'd like to see a small design of what you're proposing and what your stages are to get there.

Agree. I can create a design doc explaining the whole idea and the approach. Once we agreed, it's really better to proceed with one impactful change (even big one like we have now) rather then split it at this point to dozens of a smaller changes.

Patch Set 13:

> With smaller change we will not have a per-repo impact. No one will be noticed if something is broken after several months before we enforce busconfig acls. For example, it happened several times already when some daemons add new endpoints. 

I think this is true no matter how we do it.  I didn't want to review this commit in detail but I'm pretty sure you're already not supporting the multi-host features that were added in some repositories.

As of right now, we don't even have something to tell maintainers to look for.  We need to communicate that either way.

If we have something that is 90% working we can enable a bitbake variable to disable the wildcard file (which you did in this commit) and iterate relatively quickly on fixing up the final pieces.
 
> > 2. Configs supplied by repos.  A package should know what it wants to provide for dbus config and so it should be responsible for it, and not the meta-phosphor layer.
> 
> As per example with the certificate manager, this approach, the correct one, I agreed, will take almost forever with only one engineer being assigned for the work. And almost every time we will hit the same problem to bump openbmc main repo -- the individual repo's changes will be blocked until then. We had this situation already a week or two ago.

Those seem like poor examples to me.  Those were existing configs that you moved into those repos.  These are _new_ configs.  It should be trivial to get those installed from the repository with meson/etc.  It shouldn't even need new bitbake code.  So, you can blast these changes across all the repos and get them in (once we agree to a design).

> > 3. A design doc.  I think we have some fundamental disagreements (even within the maintainers) of how these configs should be provided: by the dbus service or the client.  I'd like to see a small design of what you're proposing and what your stages are to get there.
> 
> Agree. I can create a design doc explaining the whole idea and the approach. 

Thank you.

> Once we agreed, it's really better to proceed with one impactful change (even big one like we have now) rather then split it at this point to dozens of a smaller changes.

Let's see what the design looks like and we can discuss that as part of the staging (part of the design).  I really don't think one big change is necessary.

Patch Set 13:

For staging consider if a default allow all, even if not secure long term,  could help break up the commits in manageable pieces.  

I have no idea if this is reasonable.

Patch Set 13:

> Patch Set 13:
> 
> For staging consider if a default allow all, even if not secure long term,  could help break up the commits in manageable pieces.  
> 
> I have no idea if this is reasonable.

This is what we have today actually, which is being deleted with this commit:

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/openbmc/+/42748/13/meta-phosphor/recipes-phosphor/dbus/dbus-perms/org.openbmc.conf
How come some bb files need this explicitly set in FILES vs. some bb files don't?

It depends if we need to ship specific config in specific package. There is a default rule to ship files from "image" directory for one binary package. Perhaps (just speculating), if FILES_${PN} is not overriden in recipe, then all files from "image" will be shipped within the package.

I thought we did an extensive set of changes to depreciate this inherit

Can you explain what you are using and is it small enough to inline?
